None worse then I shall be her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Madam, Heaven is the Guardian of the just;
You cannot miss a Champion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: E're I go,
May I entreat a word?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: O yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Collumello and Almado, hear me,
I speak to you, and to your felow Peers,
Remember both by oaths and by allegiance
You are my subjects.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Madam, true, we are.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then as you ever bore respect or truth
To me as to your Soveraign, I conjure ye
Never to levy arms against the King,
Singly or openly, and never else
To justifie my right or wronge in this.
For if you do, here I proclaim ye all
Traytors to loyalty and me: for surety,
I crave your oaths a new.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Since you enforce us,
We sware: and heaven protect you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Let me be gone.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Well as they please for that: Muretto, follow.
sp.stage: Exit all but Almada and Collummello.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Here is fine work, my lord. What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Stand still while this proud Tyrant cuts our throats.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: She's wrong'd, and this is onely but a plot.
Velasco, now might binde his Country to him;
But he is grown so cowardly and base,
That boys and children beat him as they list.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have be thought me, we, with th' other Peers,
Will set a proclamation our, assuring
What worthy Knight soever undertakes,
By such a day, as Champion for the Queen.
Shall have a hundred thousand ducats paid,
Withal, what honors else he shall demand.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: This must be speeded, or 'twill come to late.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: It shall be suddain: Here our hope must stand;
Kings command Subjects; Heav'n doth Kings command.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: A coward? 'tis impossible; Velasco a coward? The brave man? The wonder of the time? Sure, Shaparoon, 'tis a meer scandal rais'd by an enemy.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: 'Tis most certain, most apparent; Taylors, Prentizes, nay, Bakers and Weavers; (things that drink cannot put spirit into, they are such mighty bread-eaters) they as I am an honest woman, fling old shoes at him, and he dares not turn back to give an angry word.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I had been sweetly promoted to such a tame Champion.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Gallants! Out upon 'em, 'tis your tough clown is your only raiser up of man or woman.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: A Proclimation is sent out for certain?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Most assuredly.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: The sum proposed, a hundred thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Present payment, without attendance.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: 'Tis a glorious reward— speak low, and observe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Whosoever, man or woman, can, or will procure any such foresaid defendant, against the said day; let them, him, or she repair to the said lords of the Councel, and give in such sufficient assurance for such defence, and they or any of them shall receive a hundred thousand ducats in ready cash; with what honors may give them, him, or her content or satisfaction.
O that I durst be valiant: A hundred thousand. A hundred thousand; how it rumbles in my chops.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Prethee, a word, my friend.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, all fair weather upon ye.
As for you, Madam, time was, I recommend to your ancient remembrance, time is past: with my service forwards and backwards, when 'tis time present, resting yours in the whole Mopas.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Very courtly and pithy.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Pray let me view your paper.

sp.speaker: Mop
sp.p: 'Tis your ladiships.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Some proclamation as I take it.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Madam Reverence, you have taken it in the right cue.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I am o'rejoy'd; there's gold for thy news. Friend. I will make thee the happiest and most welcom messenger to thy lord, that ever received thanks from him; without delay, wait on me for instructions.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I am at your ladiships beck.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: True, true, Sir, you are set high upon the stage for action. O the top of my ambition, my hearts Idol!

What a perplexity are you twin'd into? And justly; so justly, that it is hard to judge, whether your happiness were greater in the possession of an unmatchable beauty, or your present misery, by inforcing that beauty to expose her honor to so apparent a contempt: This is not the least, that might have been in time prevented.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O I am lost Muretto, my sunke eyes
Are buried in their hollows: busie thoughts
Press on like legions of infernal hags
To menace my destruction: Yet my judgment
Still prompts my senses, that my Queen is fair.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Fair! Unspeakable workmanship of Heavens bounty. Were all the skilfullest Painters that ever discern'd colours, moulded into one, to perfect an Artist. Yet that Artist should sooner want fansie or imagination, for personating a curious medal, then ever to patern a counterfeit so exquisitely excellent, as is the Queen by nature.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I have surveyed the wonder of her cheeks,
Compar'd them wth the lillies and the rose
And by my life, Muretto, Roses are
Adulterate to her blush, and lilies pale,
Examin'd with her white; yet, blear eyed fool,
I could not see those rarities before me.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.l: Every man is blind (my lord) in his own happiness, there's the curse of our mortality.
She was the very tale of the world:
Her perfections busied all tongues.
She was the onely wish of Europes chiefest Monarchs.
Whose full fruition you (and 'twas your capital sin) most inhumanly abandoned.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Villain, Petruchi, let me for ever curse him: Had he not been the man; who else had durst to hazard a denyal from her scorns?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: See now herein you are monstrous discourteous, above excuse; why, Sir, what hath Petruchi done? Which (from any King to a Vassal) al men would not eagerly have persued. Alas, my lord, his nobleness is eternal, by this means, in attempting and his felicity unmatchable, in injoying the glory of his time, a beau so conquering, so unparalell'd.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: She is superlative.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Divine.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Rich, bright.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: immortal.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Too too worthy for a man.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: The Gods might enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nature ne're fram'd so sweet a creature.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: She is self Nature's Nature.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Let me for ever curse the frail condition
Of our deluded faculties: Muretto,
Yet being all, as she is all, her best
Is worst considering that she is a wanton

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Build you a Palace, arch it with Diamonds, roof it with Carbuncles, pave it with Emraulds, daub it with Gold, furnish it with all what cost can lay on, and then seal up the doors, and at best 'tis but a solitary nest for Owles and Daws.

Beauty was not meerly created for wonder, but for use: 'Tis you were in the fault; 'tis you perswaded her, urg'd, compell'd, inforc'd her: I know it, my truth and plainness trumpets it out to ye: Besides, women (my lord) are all creatures, nor Gods nor Angels.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I must confess 'tis true, yet by my Crown
She dyes, if none defend her, I'm resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: 'Tis a heroical disposition, and with your honour she cannot, must not live. Here's the point; If she live and you receive her to favour, you will be a noted Cuckold; which is a recognizance dishonorable to all, but to a King fearfully infamous. On the other side, if you prevail, and she be put to death, you do as it were deprive the Firmanent of the Sun, and your self of the treasure of the whole earth.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Right, right, Muretto, there thou strik'st the wound
Too deeply to be cur'd, yet I must do't.
I would fain see her now.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Pray do, Sir; and let Petruchi come face to face to her; observe them both, but be very mild to both: use extremity to neither.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well counsell'd; call them hither, but none with them:
Wee'll strive with grief; Heaven! I am plung'd at full.
Never henceforward shall I slumber out
One peaceful hour; my enraged blood
Turns coward to mine honour. I could wish
My Queen might live now though I did but look
And gaze upon her cheeks, her ravishing cheeks.
But, oh, to be a Cuckold; 's death, she dyes.

sp.stage: Enter at one door Petruchi, and the other Muretto and the Queen, they stand at several ends of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: My gratious Lord.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Reach yond fair sight a chair, That man a stool, sit both, wee'l have it so.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p:
'Tis Kingly done; in any case
(my lord) curb now a while the violence of your passion, and be temperate.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis my part to kneel, for on your brow
I read sad sentence of a troubled wrath,
And that is argument enough to prove my guilt, not being worthy of your favour.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Let me kneel too, though not for pardon, yet
In duty to this presence: else I stand
As far from falsehood, as is that from truth

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, this not the promise on your part.
It is his pleasure you should sit.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: His pleasure is my law.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Let him sit too, the man,

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Sir, you are obey'd.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Between my comforts and my shame I stand
In equal distance; this way let me turn
To thee thou woman. Let me dull mine eyes
With surfeit on thy beauty. What art thou
Great dazeling splendor? Let me ever look
And dwell upon this presence.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I am distract. Say? What! Do not, do not—

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: My lord the King-Way, Sir?— He is in a trance, or else metamorphis'd to some some pillar of marble: How fixedly a' stands.
D'ee hear, Sir? What d'ee dream on?
My lord, this is your Queen speak to her.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: May I presume with my irreverent lips
To touch your sacred hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am too wretched
To be thought but the subject of your mirth.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why she can speak, Muretto? O tell me pray,
And make me ever, ever fortunate;
Are you a mortal creature? Are ye indeed
Moulded of flesh and blood like other women?
Can you be pittiful? Can ye vouchsafe
To entertain fair parley? Can you love,
Or grant me leave to love you; can you, say?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You know too well, my lord, instead of granting,
I ow a duty, and must sue to you,
If I may not displease.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Now I am great,
You are my Queen, and I have wrong'd a merit,
More then my service in the humblest lowness
Can ever recompence. I'll rather wish
To meet whole hosts of dangers, and encounter
The flabled whips of steel, then ever part
From those sweet eyes: not time shall sue divorce
'Twixt me and this great miracle of Nature.
Muretto?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Soveraign Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'll turn away,
And mourn my former errors— Worse then death
Look where a Basilisk with murthering flames
Of poyson, strikes me Blinde. Insatiate tempter,
Patern of lust, 'tis thou alone hast sundred
Our lawful bride bed, planted on my crest
The horned Satyrs badge; hast soyl'd a beauty
As glorious, as sits yonder on her front.
Kill him, Muretto, why should he receive
The benefit of the law, that us'd no law
In my dishonours?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Were you more a King
Then Royalty can make you, though opprest
By your commanding powers, yea, and orb'd
In bonds most falsely, yet, give me a sword
And strip me to my shirt, I will defend
Her spotles vertue, and no more esteem,
In such a noble cause, an host of Kings,
Then a poor stingless swarm of buzzing flies.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Petruchi, in those words thou dost condemn
Thy loyalty to me, I shall disclaim
All good opinion of thy worth or truth,
If thou persevere to affront my lord.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then I have done. Here's misery unspeakable;
Rather to yeeld me guilty wrongfully,
Then contradict my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: High impudence.
Could she be ten times fairer then she is,
Yet I would be reveng'd. You sweet, I would
Again— Her beams quite blast me.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: If you will be an Eaglet of the right aery, you must endure the Sun. Can you chuse but love her?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: No by the Stars. Why would not you be honest; and know how I do dore?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: May I be bold
To say I am, and not offend?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
Say so for heavens love, though you be as fowl
As sin can black your purity. Yet tell me
That you are white and chast; That while you live
The span of your few dayes, I may rejoyce
In my deluded follies; least I dye
Through anguish, e're I have reveng'd my iniury,
And so leave you behind me for another;
That were intollerable.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Heaven knows, I ne're abus'd my self or you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: As much swore I, and truly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou proud Devil.
Thou hast a lying tongue; They are consented.
In mischief. Get ye hence seducing horrors.
I'll stop mine eyes and ears till you are gone.
As you would be more merciful, away,
Or as you would finde mercy.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Sir, they are gone.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And she too then let me be seen no more.
I am distracted, both waies I feel my blame;
To leave her death, to live with her is shame.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Fare ye well King, this is admirable, I will be chronicled, all my business ripens to my wishes. And if honest intentions thrive so succesfully; I will henceforth build upon this assurance, that there can hardly be a greater Hell or Damnation, then in being a Villane upon earth.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: I am wonder stricken— And were you i'faith the she indeed, that turn'd my Lords heart so handsomly, so cunningly? O how I reverence wit. Well, lady, you are as pestilent a piece of policy, as ever made an ass of love.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: But, Lodovico, I'll salve all again quickly.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Yes indeed forsooth, she has the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: You have undertaken with the lords already, you say.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I have, and my life is at stake, but I fear not that.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Pish, you have no need; one smile, or kinde simper from you does all; I warrant ye the sight of so much gold, as you are to receive, hath quickned your love infinitely.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I was not worthy of my lords love before; I was too poor: but now two hundred thousand ducats, is a dower sit for a lord.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Marry is't. I applaud your consideration.
'Twas neatly thought on.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Have you prevail'd yet, lady, time runs on,
You must not dally.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Good my lords, fear nothing:
Were it but two hours to't, I should be ready.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: He comes himself, 'tis fit we stood unseen.
Ply him soundly, lady.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Let us withdraw then.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: I cannot be alone, still I am hunted
With my confounding thoughts: Too late I finde,
How passions at their best are but sly traytors
To ruin honour. That which we call love,
Was by the wisest power above forethought
To check our pride. Thus when men are blown up
At the highest of conceit, then they fall down
Even by the peevish follies of their frailties.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: The best of my lord Velasco's wishes ever.
Crown him with all true content.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Cry ye mercy, Lady.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I come to chide you my Lord; can it be possible that ever any man could so sincerely profess such a mightiness of affection, as you have done to me, and forget it all so soon, and so unkindely.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Are you a true very lover, or are you bound
For pennance to walk to some holy shrine
In visitation? I have seen that face.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Have you so? O you are a hot lover; a woman is in fine case to weep out her eyes for so uncertain a friend, as your protestations urg'd me to conceive you: But come I know what you'll say aforehand, I know you are angry.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to be my own tormentor.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Very angry, extreamly angry; But as I respect perfection, tis more then I deserve.
Little know you the misery I have endured, and all about a hasty word of nothing, and I'll have it prove nothing e're we part.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Her pride hath made her lunatick, alas!
She hath quite lost her wits, those are the fruits
Of scorns and mockeries.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: To witness how indearedly I prefer your merits, and love your person; in a word, my lord, I absolve you, and set you free from the injunction I bound you in; as I desire to thrive, I meant all but for a tryal in jest.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: these are no words of madness; whither tends
The extremity of your invention, Lady?
I'll swear no more.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I was too blame, but one fault( me thinks) is to be pardoned, when I am yours and you firmly mine: I'll bear with many in you.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: So, if you be in earnest; What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: The sum of all is, that I know it suits not with the bravery of the lord Velasco's spirit, to suffer his Queen and soveraign stand wrongfully accused of dishonour, and dye shamefully for a fault never committed.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Why 'tis no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Nor shall it be of mine: Go be a famous subject; be a ransomer of thy Queen from dangers, be registred thy Countries patron: Fight in defence of the fairest and innocentest princess alive: I with my heart release you.
First conquer; that done, enjoy me ever for thy wife: Velasco, I am thine.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Pish, you release me, all their cunning strains
Of policy that set you now a work,
To treble ruin me, in life, fame, soul,
Are foolish and unable to draw down
A greater wrath upon my head; in troth
You take a wrong course lady.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Very good, Sir, 'tis prettily put off, and wondrous modestly. I protest, no man hath enjoyn'd me to this task; 'tis onely to do service to the State, and honour to you.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: No man enjoyn'd you but your self?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: None else, as I ever had truth in me.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Know then from me, you are a wicked woman,
And avarice, not love to me, hath forc'd ye
To practice on my weakness. I could raile,
Be most uncivil; But take all in short:
I know you not.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Better and better, the man will triumph anon sure; Prethee, good dissemble no longer; I say you shall fight, I'll have it so: I command you fight, by this kiss you shall.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Forbear, let me in peace bid you forbear;
I will be henceforth still a stranger to you,
Ever a stranger, look, look up, up there
My oath is bookt, no humane power can free me.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I grant you none but I.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Be not deceived, I have
Forgot your scorns; you are lost to me,
Witness the Genius of this place, how e're
You tempt my constancy, I dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Not dare to fight, what not for me?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: No Lady.
I durst not, must not, cannot, will not fight.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: O me und one.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: What ayles you?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Now my life
Hath run it's last for I have pawn'd it Sir
To bring you forth as champion for the Queen.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: And so should have the promis'd Gold.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I, I.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: You have reveng'd my wrongs upon your selfe.
I cannot helpe you, nay alas you know
It lay not in me.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: O take pitty on mee,
Look heer, I hold my hands up, bend my knees,
Heaven can require no more.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Then kneel to heaven
I am no God, I cannot do you good.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Shall not my tears prevayle? hard-hearted Man.
Dissembler, loves dishonour, bloody butcher
Of a poor Lady, be assured my Ghost
Shall haunt thy soule when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Your curse
Is falne upon your own head, herein show
A noble piety, to beare your death
With resolution, and for finall answer
Lady I will not fight to gain the world.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Gone! I have found at length my just reward,
And henceforth must prepare to welcom Death.

sp.speaker: Velasco
sp.l: I begin to love thee now.
Now I perceave thou art a noble man,
Compos'd of Goodnes, what a foole was I?
It grieves me more to loose him then to die.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: Lady we have heard all that now hath past,
You have deceav'd your selfe and us, the time
We should have spent in seeking other means.
Is lost, of which you are the cause.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And for it
The senats strickt decree craves execution,
What can you say?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: My Lords I can no more but yeild me to the law.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: O that ever you were born, you have made a sweet hand on't, have you not.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Here is the right recompence of a vain confidence, Mistresse: But I will not torture you being so neer your end, lady say your prayers and die in Charity, that's all the pitty I can take on ye

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Ten times the gold you should have had, now Lady cannot release you.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: You alone are shee
Ruins your country. Heres the price of sin,
Ill thrift, all loose in seeking all to win.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Nay even go thy ways, 'tis an old proverbe that leachery and covetousnes go together, and 'tis a true one too, But I'le shift for one.
If some proper squire or lustly yeoman have a mind to any thing I have about me, a shall soon know what to trust too for I see the times are very troublesome.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Now is the prosperous season when the whole round of the planets are coupling together. Let birds and beasts observe valentines day, I am a man and all times are with me in season, this same Court ease hath sett my blood on tiptoe, I am Madder then a march hare.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Blessing on your fair face, your handsome hand, your clean foot sir, are you a Courtien sir?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Good starrs direct me, sweet woman, I am a Courtier, if you have any suit, what is't, what is't? be short.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Lord what a Courteous proper man 'a is, trust me, 'a hath a most eloquent heard.— Suit Sir, Yes Sir, I am a countrey gentlewoman by father and Mothers side, one that comes to see fashions and learne newes. And How I pray sir (if I may be so bold to aske) stand things at Court Sir now a dayes?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: A very modest necessary and discreet Question.
Indeed Mistris Countrey-Gentlewoman, things at Court stand as they were over wont, some stiffe and some slacke, every thing according to the imployment it hath.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Mary, the more pitty sir, that they have not all good doing a like, methinkes, they should be all and at all times ready heer.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: You speake by a figure, by your leave, in that.
But because you are a stranger, I will a little more amply informe you.

Heer at our Courts of Arragon, Schollars for the most part are the veriest fooles for that they are allways, beggerly and prowd. And foolish citizens the wisest schollars for that they never run at charges for greater learning to cast up their reck'nings, then their Horn-book.

Here every old lady is cheaper then a proctor, and will as finely convey an open act, without any danger of a consistory. Love and money sweepes all before them, be they cut or longtayle. Do not I deserve a kisse for this discovery Mistris.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: A kisse, O my dear chastity, yes indeed forsooth, and I pray please your selfe.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Good wench by venus, but are you any thing rich?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Rich enough to serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I see you are reasonable fair.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I ever thought my selfe so.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Will you survey my lodgings?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: At your pleasure sir being under your gard as I am.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Sirrha Mopas, If my mistresse say but the word, thou shalt see what an exployt, I will doe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: You'le undertake it you say, though your throat be cut in your own defence, 'tis but manslaughter you can never be hang'd for it.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Nay I am resolute in that point, heer's my hand, let him shrinke, that list, I'le not flinch a hayres breadth Mopas.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: What, old huddle and twang so close at it, and the dog dayes so neer, Heark ye, your lady is going the way of all flesh. And so is that schollar with you methinkes, though not in the same cue, is 'a not?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: 'A has promist to tell me my fortune at his chamber, and do me some other good for my ladies safety.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I have spoken, the planets shall be rul'd by me, Captain, you know they shall.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Let the planets hang themselves in the elements, what care I, I have other matters to trouble my braines.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Signior Pynto take her to you, so true a mettall'd blade as ever was turn'd into a dudgion, hearke in your eare.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: I know not how to trust you, you ar all so fickle so unconstant.

sp.speaker: Herop.
sp.l: If I faile
Let me be mark't a Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.l: I apprehend you use him kindly still,
See where 'a is, Captain you are well mett,
Wer'e's one whose heart you have.

sp.speaker: Herop.
sp.p: He knowes he has.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Why by my truth I thanke you forsooth, 'tis more of your curtesie then my deserving; but I shall study to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Herop.
sp.p: I hope so, and doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Madam Cosen Shaproon.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: You are welcom sir.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Cosen, Nay then I smell she is a gentlewoman indeed.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Yes, and as antiently descended as Flesh and blood can derive her.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I am a made man and I will have her.

sp.speaker: Herop.
sp.p: You'le walke with me sir?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Even through fire and water. sweet Mistres.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.l: Let's every one to what concerns us most,
For now's the time all must be sav'd or lost,

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: This is not kindly done, nor like a friend.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Keep your chamber then, what should owles and bats do abroad by day light? why, you are become so notoriously ridiculous, that a Craven is reputed of nobler spirit amongst birds, then Velasco among men.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Why Lodovico dost thou tempt my wrongs?
O friend, 'tis not an honor or a fame
Can be a gain to me, though I should dare
To entertain this Combatt, say my fate
Did crown mine arm with conquest of the King,
Put case the cause add glory to the justice
Of my prevaling sword? what can I win?
Saving a pair of lives I lose a soule,
My rich soule Lodovico, Does not yet
The heart even shrill within thee? All thy spirits
Melt into Passions, All thy manhood stagger
Like mine? Nay canst thou chuse but now confess
That this word Coward is a name of Dignity?

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Faint hearts and strong toungs are the tokens of many a tall prattling Ghossipe. Yet the truth is you have halfe convinced me, But to what end will you be a looker on the Tragedy of this shee Beast? it will but breed your greater vexation.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I hope not so, I looke for Comfort in't.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Mass: that may be too, It cannot but make your melancholy a little merry, to see the woodcockes neck caught in a worse noose, then shee had set for you.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: That's but a poor revenge, I'de rather weep
On her behalfe, but that I hope her courage
Will triumph over Death.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: My Lord they come.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Let me stand back unseen, Good Angells guard her.

sp.stage: Enter executioner before Salassa, her Hayre loose, after her, Almada, Collumello and officers.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Tis a sad welcom.
To bid you welcome to the stroak of Death.
Yet you are come too't Lady.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: And a cause
Throughout the land will be your generall knell,
For having bin the wilfull overthrow,
First of your Countreys Champion, next your Queen,
Your Lawfull Soveraign, who this very day.
Must act a part which you must act before, but with less guilt.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Use no long speeches lady,
The danger of the time, calls us away,
We cannot listen to your farewells now.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: I have few words to say, my heart is lodg'd
In you same upper Parliament, yet now
If ere I part, and shall be seen no more,
Some man of mercy could but truly speake
One word of pardon from the Lord Velasco,
My peace were made in earth, and I should fly
With wings of speed to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Pish here's not any.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Not any? on then, why should I prolong
A minute more of life, that live so late,
Where most I strive for love to purchace hate,
Beare witnes Lords I wish not to call back
My younger dayes in promise that I would
Redeem my fault and do Velasco right,
But could I but reverse the doom of time,
I would with humblest suit make prayers to heaven
For his long florishing welfare.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Dispatch, dispatch;
You should have thought on this before, pray now
For your own health, for you have need to pray.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Madam Salassa, I am bold to take leave of ye before your long journey: All the comfort that I can give you is, that the weather is like to hold very fair, you need not take much care for either hood or cloke for the matter.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Are you come? Worthy Sir, then I may hope
Your noble friend hath sent one gentle sigh
To grace my funeral: For vertues sake
Give me a life in death; tell me, O tell me,
If he but seal my pardon, all is well.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Say ye so? Why then in a word, go merrily up the stayers; my lord Velasco desires Heaven may as heartily forgive him, as he does you.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Enough, I thank his bounty, on I go
To smile on horror: so, so, I'm up.
Great in my lowness, and to witness further
My humbleness, here let me kneel and breath
My penitence: O women in my fall,
Remember that your beauties, youth and pride
Are but gay tempters, 'less you wisely shun
The errors of your frailties: let me ever
Be an example to all fickle dames,
That folly is no shrine for vertuous names.
Heaven pardon all my vanities, and free
The lord Velasco, what e're come of me.
Bless, bless, the lord Velasco.— Strike.
sp.stage: As he is about to strike, Velasco steps out.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Villain, hold, hold! Or thou dyest, Slave.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: What means that countermand?

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Hey, do! More news yet, you will not be valiant when 'tis too late, I trust?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Woman, come down: Who lends me now a sword?

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Marry, that do I, Sir, I am your first man; Here, here, here, take heed you do not hurt your fingers; 'twill cut plaguely: and what will you do with it?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Base woman, take thy life, thy cursed life,
I set thee free, and for it pawn a soul:
But that I know heaven hath more store of mercy,
Then thou and all thy sex of sin and falsehood.
My Lords, I now stand Champion for the Queen:
Doth that discharge her?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Bravest man, it doth:
Lady, y'are safe; now, Officers away.
This is a blessed hour!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: You shall for ever
Bind us your servants.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Aha: Why then, however things happen, let them fall, as they fall. God a' mercy, my lord, at last.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hark how the people ring a peal of joy.
For this good news. My lord, time steals away;
We may not linger now.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: You give me life;
Take it not, Sir, away again. I see
Upon your troubled eyes such discontent
As frights my trembling heart; Dear Sir—

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: The Gold
You hazarded your life for, is your own,
You may receive it at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yes,
'Tis ready for you, lady.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Gold? Let gold,
And all the treasures of the earth besides
Perish like trash; I value nothing, Sir,
But your assured love.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: My love! Vain woman,
Henceforth thus turn I from thee, never look
For Apish dotage, for a smile, a how d'ee,
A fare ye well, a thought from me: let Snakes
Live in my bosom, and with muderous stinges
Infect the vital warmth, that lends them life,
If ever I remember thee or thine.
If I prevail, my services shall crave
But one reward, which shall be, if that ever
Thou come but in my sight, the State wil please
To banish thee the land; or else I vow,
My self to leave it.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: My ill purchast life!

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Ill purchast life, indeed, whose ransom craves
A sadder price, then price of bloodshed saves.
Go, learn bad woman, what it is, how foul,
By gaining of a life, to lose a soul.
The price of one oul doth exceed as far
A life here, as the Sun in light a Star.
Here though we live some threescore years, or more,
Yet we must dye at last, and quit the score
We ow to nature. But the soul once dying,
Dyes ever, ever; no repurifying;
No earnest sighs or grones; no intercession;
No tears; no pennance; no too late confession
Can move the ear of justice, if it doom
A soul past cure to an infernal tomb.
Make use of this Salassa.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.l: Think upon that now, and take heed, you look
My lord no more in the face.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Goodness protect him! now my life so late
I strove to save, which being sav'd I hate.

sp.stage: Enter Alphonso armed all save the head, leading the Queen, a Herauld going before, Muretto, Herophil, a Guard.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Are you resolv'd to dye?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: When life is irksom
Death is a happiness.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Yes, if the cause
Make it not infamous: But when a beauty
So most incomparable as yours, is blemish'd
With the dishonorable stamp of whoredom:
When your black tainted name, which should have been
(Had you preserv'd it nobly) your best Chronicle,
Wherein you might have liv'd, when this is stain'd,
And justly too; then death doth but heap
Affliction on the dying. Yet you see
With what a sympathie of equal grief
I mourn your ruine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Would you could as clearly
Perceive mine innocence, as I can clearly
Protest it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Fy to justify a sin
Is worse then to commit it, now y'are faulty.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: What a royall pair of excellent creatures are heer both upon the castaway. It were a saint like mercy in you (my Lord) to remitt the memory of a past errour. And in you Madam (if you be guilty of the supposed crime) to submitt your selfe to the King. I dare promise, his love to you is so unfayned, that it will relent in your humility. Pray do, good Madam do.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: But how if I be free?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: By any means, for your honors cause do not yeeld then one jot. Let not the faint feare of Death deject you before the royalty of an erected heart. D'ee heare this my Lord, 'tis a doubtfull case, almost impossible to be decided, Look upon her well, as I hope to prosper, shee hath a most vertuous, a most innocent countenance. Never heed it. I know my Lord your jealousy and your affections wrestle together within you for them astery. Mark her beauty throughly. Now by all the power of Love, tis pitty Shee should not be as fair within as without.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Could that be prov'd, I'de give my kingdom straight
And live a slave to her, and her perfections.
Lords welcome, see thus arm in arm we pace
To the wide theater of blood and shame
My Queen and I, my Queen? had shee bin still
As shee was, mine, we might have liv'd too happ'ly,
For eithers comfort. Heer on this sweet modell,
This plott of wonder, this fair face, stands fixt
My whole felicity on earth. In witnes
Whereof, behold (my Lords) those manly tears
Which her unkindnes and my cruell fate
Force from their quiet springs, They speak alowd
To all this open ayre, their publick eyes,
That whither I kill or dy in this attempt:
I shall in both be vanquisht.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: 'Tis strange my Lord
Your love should seem so mighty in your hatred.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Muretto go, and guard Petruchy safe.
We must be stout now, and give over whineing.
He shall confesse strange things (my Lords) I warrant ye,
Comes not a champion yet?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: None dares I hope.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: The Queen you know, hath bound us all by Oath,
We must not undertake to combat you
Although the cause should prove apparent for her.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Must not? why then y'are cowards all, all base,
And fall off from your duties, but you know
Her follies are notorious, none dare's stand
To justify a sin, they see so playnely.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You are too hard a censurer.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Give me your hand, farewell, thus from my joy's
I part, I ever part, Yet good my Lords,
Place her on yonder throne, where shee may sit
Just in mine eye, that so if strength should fail,
I might fetch double strength from her sweet beauty.
I'le heare no answers.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Heaven be always guard
To Noble actions

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: Heer's a medley love
That kills in Curtesie.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Herauld sound a warning to all defendants— What comes no one forth: How like you this my Lords? Sirrah sound again.

sp.stage: A Trumpet within Enter herauld sounding, after him Velasco arm'd all save the head, Lodovico and attendants.

sp.speaker: Velasco?
sp.l: ha? art thou the man? although
Thy cowardice hath publisht thee so base,
As that it is an injury to honour
To fight with one that hath been baffl'd scorn'd,
Yet I will bid thee welcom.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Nobly spoken.
Past times can tell you sir, I was no coward,
And now the justice of a gallant quarrell
Shall new revive my dulnes, Yonder sits
A Queen as free from stain, of your disgrace,
As you are fowle in urging it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou talk'st couragiously, I love thee for it,
And, if thou canst make good what thou avouchest,
I'le kneel to thee, as to another nature

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: We come not heer to chide, My sword shall thunder
The right for which I strike.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Traytor to loyalty,
Rash and unknown fool, what desperate lunacy
Hath led thee on to draw thy treacherous sword
Against thy King, upon a ground so giddy
That thou art but a stranger in the cause
Thou wouldst defend, By all my royall blood
If thou prevailst, thy head shal answer it.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Madam you wrong his truth, and your own fame.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: You violate the liberty of armes.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Pish, listen not to her, 'tis I'me your man.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why foolish Lords, unsensible and false,
Can any drop of blood be drawn from him
My Lord, your King, which is not drawn from me?
Velasco by the duty that thou ow'st me
I charge thee to lay by thy armes.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: I must not,
Unles this man whom you call king, confess
That he hath wrong'd your honor.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Wilt thou fight then
When I command the contrary?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Velasco. heare me once more, thou were wont
To be as pittifull as thou wert valiant,
I will entreat thee gentle kind Velasco,
A weeping Queen sues to thee, Doe not fight,
Velasco, every blow thou givest the King,
Wounds mee, didst ever love? Velasco hear me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Shee must not be endur'd.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Nor can shee win me,
Blush you my Lord at this.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O let me dy
Rather then see my Lord affronted thus

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Hold up the Queen, she swouns.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Madam Deare Madam.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: Can you see her and not be toucht my Lord?
Was ever woman false that lov'd so truly

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: 'Tis all dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: You dishonour her,
To prove it I'le fight both quarrels now.

sp.stage: Enter a herauld sounding a trumpett. after him Petruchi arm'd head and all.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Heydo? here comes more work for mettall men.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Another who should he be?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Speake what art thou?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: One that am summon'd from the power above
To guard the innocence of that fair Queen
Not more against the man that would accuse her
Then all the world besides.
Th'art welcome too.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: You come too late friend, I am he alone
Stand ready to defend that gracious beauty.
You may return.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ther's not a man alive:
Hath interest in this quarrel but my selfe,
I out of mine own knowledg can avouch.
Her accusation to be meerly false,
As hel it selfe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What mortall man is he,
So wilfull in his confidence, can sweare
More then he knowes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: I swear but what I know.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Hast thou a name?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, helpe my beaver down,
D'ee know me now?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Petruchi! death of manhood,
I am plainly bought & sold, why wher's Muretto?

sp.stage: Enter Muretto with a sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Here as ready to stand in defence of that Miracle of chast women, as any man in this presence.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Are all conspir'd against me? what thou too?
Now by my fathers ashes, by my life
Thou art a villain, a grosse rank'rous villain.
Did'st not thou only first inforce my thoughts to jealousy?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Tis true I did.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay more,
Didst not thou feed those thoughts with fresh supplies
Nam'd every circumstance?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: All this I grant.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Dost grant it, Dog, slave, Hel-hound?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Heare him good my Lord, let us perswade ye,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What canst thou say Impostor? speake and choake.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: I have not deserv'd this my Lord, and you shall find it, 'tis true, I must confesse, that I was the only instrument to incense you to this distemperature and I am prowd to say it, and say it again before this noble presence, that I was my selfe the only man.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Insufferable Devil!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Pray my Lord.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Wonder not my Lords, but lend mee your attentions, I saw with what violence he pursude his resolutions not more in detestation of the Queen in particular, then of all her sex in generall. That I may not weary your patience: I bent all my Studies to devise, which way I might do service to my country, by reclayming the distraction of his discontents. And having felt his disposition in every pulse, I found him most addicted to this pestilence of jealosy with a strong persuasion of which; I from time to time, ever fed him by degrees, till I brought the Queen and the noble Petruchi into the dangers they yet stand in. But with all (and herin I appeale to your Majesties own approbation) I season'd my words with such an intermixing the praises of the Queens bewty, that from jealosy. I drew the King into a serious examination of her perfections.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Thus farr I must acknowledg, he speaks truth.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: At length having found him indeed surely affected, I perceav'd, that nothing but the suppos'd blemish of her dishonour, could work a second divorce between them.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: True, truly fates own truth.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Now my Lords, to cleer that imputation, I knew how easie it would be, by the apparent certainty it selfe, In all which, if I have erred, it is the error of a loyall service. Only I must ever acknowledg how justly I have deserved a punishment, in drawing so vertuous a princesses honor into publick question; and humbly referr my selfe to her gracious clemency, and your noble constructions.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: But can, can this be so?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Let me ever else, be the subject of your rage, in the sufferance of any torture.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And is shee chast Petruchi?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Chast by vertue,
As is the new born virgin, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: I ever whisperd so much in your ears my Lord, and told you, that it was impossible such singular endowments by nature, should yeild to the corruption so much, as of an unworthy thought.
Did I not tell you so from time to time,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lay by your arms, my lords, and joyn with me.
Let's kneel to this (what shall I call her?) Woman?
No, she's an Angel. Glory of Creation, All kneel.
Can you forget my wickedness? Your Peers,
Your Senators, your bravest men, make suit on my behalf. Why speak ye not, my lords?
I am I know too vile to be remitted, But she is merciful.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Great Soveraign Lady—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Be not so low, my lord, in your own thoughts:
You are, as you were, Soveraign of my heart;
And I must kneel to you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: But will you love me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: 'Tis my part to ask that: will you love me?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ever, yours ever; let this kiss new marry us. What say?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It does; and heaven it self can tell
I never did, nor will wrong our first loves.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Speak it no more. Let's rise, now I am King
Of two rich Kingdoms, as the world affords:
The Kingdom of thy beauty, and this land.
But what rests for Muretto?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I account my worthiest thanks his debt.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And he deserves all honor, all respect.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Thus my imbraces
Can witness how I truly am his friend.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: And I whilst I have life.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Nay when I am dead I, will appear again, clap thee on the shoulder and cry, God a' mercy old Suresby.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I must ask pardon of him, still I thought
His plot had aim'd all at his own behoof,
But I am sorry for that misconceit.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: My lords, What I have been heretofore, I cannot altogether excuse; but I am sure my desires were alwaies honest, however my low fortune kept me down: But now I finde 'tis your honest man is your honest man still, howere the world go.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Muretto, Whilst I live thou shalt be neer me,
As thou deservest: And noble Gentlemen
I am in all your debts: henceforth beleeve me,
I'll strive to be a servant to the State.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long live happy both.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: But where are now my brace of new-made Courtiers,
My Scholler and my Captain?

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: I cry guilty, there is a large story depends upon their exploits, my Lord; for both they thinking in such perilous times to be shifting every man for one, have took a passing provident course to live without help hereafter. The man in the moon, Signior Pynto, for the raising of his fortune a Planet higher, is by this time married to a kinde of loose-bodied widow, called by Sirname a Bawde; one that if he follow wholesom instructions, will maintain him, there's no question on't, the captain for his part, is somwhat more delicately resolv'd for as adventurous (though not as frail) a piece of service. For he in hope to marry this lady, attending on the Queen, granted Petruchi his liberty, and by this time hath received a sufficient quietus est.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Are these my trusty servants? What a blindness was I led into!

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: If your Highnesses both will in these daies of mirth crown the Comedy; first let me from the Queens royal gift be bold to receive Herophil for my wife; She and I are resolv'd of the business already.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: With all my heart, I think her well bestow'd,
If she her self consents.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: My duty, Madam,
Shall ever speak my thankfulness, in this
I reckon all my services rewarded.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Much comfort to you friend.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: All joy and peace.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: My duty to my Soveraigns, to all therest at once, my heartiest heartiest thanks. Now, lady, you are mine; why so, here's short work to begin with. If in the end we make long work, and beget a race of mad-caps, we shall but do as our fathers and mothers did, and they must be cared for.

sp.stage: Enter Pynto, Bufo, Mopas with a tire upon his head, and Shaparoon:

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Follow me not bawde; my lord the King;
My love, justice, justice.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Justice to me, I was like to have been married to these black muschatoes insteed of that lady.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I to this ugly bawde.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Justice.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hence you ridiculous fools, I banish you
For ever from my presence: Sirrah, to thee
I give the charge, that they be forth with stript,
And put into such rags they came to Court in;
And so turn'd off.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Dost hear me King?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: King hear me, I'me the wiser man.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: No more I say.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Come away, come away for shame, you see what 'tis to be given to the flesh: the itch of letchery must be cured with the whip of correction. Away, away.
sp.stage: Exeunt Bufo, Pynto, Mopas and Shaparoon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What else remains
But to conclude this day in Hymen's Feasts?
sp.stage: Enter Salassa her hair loose, a white rod in her hand, two or three with bags of money.
sp.l: To whom; for what;
Your meaning, name, and errand?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: At those feet
Lay down those sums of gold, the price of guilt,
Of shame, of horror.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What new riddle's this?
sp.stage: Muretto whispers the King, Collumello the Queen.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: My Gratious lord.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I shall inform your Highness.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Woman of impudence.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Your looks proclaim
My sentence banishment, or if you think
The word of banishment too hard to utter.
But turn away, my lord, and without accent
I'll understand my doom, I'll take my leave,
And like a penitentiary walk
Many miles hence to a religious shrine
Of some chast sainted Nun, and wash my fin off
In tears of penance, to my last of breath.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: You come to new torment me.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I am gone, my lord; I go for ever.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Faith be merciful, the woman will prove a wife worth the having, I'll Pass my word.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: E'ne so; stay, lady, I command you, stay.
Velasco here's occasion proffer'd now
For me to purchase some deserving favour
From woman; honour me in my first suit;
Remit and love that lady.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Good my lord.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I must not be deny'd, my Queen
Shall joyn with me to mediate for her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, I dare undertake, she that presents
Her pennance in such sorrow, hearty sorrow,
Will know how to redeem the time with duty,
With love, obedience.

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p:
D'ee hear, my lord; all the ladies in Arragon, and my wife among the rest, will bait ye like so many wild cats,
if you should triumph over a poor yeelding creature, that does in a manner lye down to ye of her own accord. Come, I know you love her with all the very vaines of your heart.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: There's more hope of one woman reclaim'd (my lord) then of many conceited of their own innocence, which indeed they never have but in conceit.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: To strive against the ordinance of fate,
I finde is all in vain: Lady, your hand,
I must confess I love you, and I hope
Our faults shall be redeem'd in being henceforth
True votaries to vertue, and the faith
Our mutual vows shal to each other ow.
Say, are you mine, resolv'd?

sp.speaker: Lodov.
sp.p: Why that's well said.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Yours, as you please to have me:

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Here then ends
All memory of any former strife:
He hath enough who hath a vertuous wife.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long joy to both.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: The money we return
Where it is due; and for Velasco's merits
Will double it. Thus after storms a calm
Is ever welcomest: Now we have past
The worst, and all I hope is well at last

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
